questions.text: Highest amount of saturated fatty acid is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Palm oil is a vegetable oil derived from the fruit of oil palm trees. It contains a high proportion of saturated fatty acids, particularly palmitic acid and stearic acid. Due to its high saturated fat content, palm oil is often used in food processing and cooking, especially in products like margarine, baked goods, and processed foods.

Soybean oil (Option A): Soybean oil is primarily composed of unsaturated fatty acids, including both monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats. It contains relatively low levels of saturated fatty acids compared to other oils.

Groundnut (Peanut) oil (Option B): Similar to soybean oil, groundnut oil is predominantly made up of unsaturated fatty acids, with lower levels of saturated fatty acids. It is not known for having the highest amount of saturated fats.

Sunflower oil (Option D): Sunflower oil is predominantly composed of unsaturated fats, including both monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fatty acids. It contains lower levels of saturated fatty acids compared to palm oil.

questions.text: All are saturated fatty acids except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Oleic acid is a monounsaturated fatty acid. Unlike saturated fatty acids, it has one double bond between carbon atoms in the hydrocarbon chain. This double bond results in the loss of two hydrogen atoms and creates a kink in the hydrocarbon chain.

Lauric acid (Option A): Lauric acid is a saturated fatty acid. It is commonly found in coconut oil and palm kernel oil. Saturated fatty acids do not have any double bonds between carbon atoms, meaning that all carbon atoms are saturated with hydrogen atoms.

Palmitic acid (Option C): Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid. It is one of the most common saturated fatty acids found in both animal and plant fats. It has a straight hydrocarbon chain with no double bonds between carbon atoms.

Stearic acid (Option D): Stearic acid is also a saturated fatty acid. Like palmitic acid, it is commonly found in both animal and plant fats. It has a straight hydrocarbon chain with no double bonds between carbon atoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cardioprotective fatty acid
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Omega-3 fatty acids, particularly eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), are well-known for their cardioprotective effects.

  • They have been shown to reduce triglyceride levels, decrease inflammation, improve endothelial function, and reduce the risk of cardiovascular events such as heart attacks and strokes.

Palmitic acid (Option A): Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid that is commonly found in both animal and plant fats. It is not considered cardioprotective and, in high amounts, may contribute to increased levels of LDL (low-density lipoprotein) cholesterol, which is associated with an increased risk of heart disease.

Stearic acid (Option B): Stearic acid is also a saturated fatty acid found in various animal and plant fats. While it is considered to have a neutral effect on cholesterol levels compared to other saturated fats, it is not typically considered cardioprotective like omega-3 fatty acids.

Oleic acid (Option D): Oleic acid is a monounsaturated fatty acid found in high amounts in olive oil, nuts, and avocados. While it is considered to have some health benefits, including potentially reducing LDL cholesterol levels, it is not specifically known for its cardioprotective effects like omega-3 fatty acids.

questions.text: The most important essential fatty acid is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Linoleic acid is an essential omega-6 fatty acid. It is considered the most important essential fatty acid because it is the precursor for the synthesis of other important omega-6 fatty acids, such as arachidonic acid.

  • Linoleic acid is vital for maintaining skin health, supporting the immune system, and regulating inflammation.
  • Safflower oil is known to be one of the richest sources of this essential fatty acid.

Linolenic acid (Option B): This option appears to be a misspelling of alpha-linolenic acid, which is an essential omega-3 fatty acid. While alpha-linolenic acid is important for health, particularly for its role in producing other omega-3 fatty acids like eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), it is not considered the most important essential fatty acid. Linoleic acid is generally considered more critical due to its prevalence in the diet and its role as a precursor for other fatty acids.

Arachidonic acid (Option C): Arachidonic acid is an omega-6 fatty acid that is synthesized in the body from linoleic acid. While arachidonic acid plays important roles in various physiological processes, it is not considered the most important essential fatty acid. Linoleic acid, as the precursor for arachidonic acid synthesis, is considered more critical.

Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) (Option D): EPA is an omega-3 fatty acid found in fatty fish and algae. While EPA is important for health, particularly for its cardiovascular benefits and anti-inflammatory properties, it is not considered the most important essential fatty acid. Linoleic acid, which is an omega-6 fatty acid, is generally considered more critical due to its essentiality and widespread presence in the diet.

questions.text: The daily requirement of dietary fiber in an adult is____.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ideal fibre intake is approximately 30 grams per 2,000 kcal consumed.

General Dietary Guidance:

  • Individuals consuming a balanced diet typically get adequate fibre (also known as roughage).
  • Given the decline in fibre content of modern diets, especially due to increased processing, boosting fibre intake - particularly from whole cereals and grains - is recommended.
  • The ideal fibre intake is approximately 30 grams per 2,000 kcal consumed.
  • Consuming over 60 grams per day may:
    • Hinders nutrient absorption
    • Causes bowel irritation or discomfort

Estimated Fibre Intake in Western India (grams/day):

Fibre content depends on the type and amount of:

  • Cereals
  • Pulses
  • Whole grains
  • Vegetables
  • Millets

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a component of dietary fibre
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Agar is a gelatinous substance derived from seaweed and is commonly used as a thickening agent in food preparation and as a medium for microbiological culture.

  • While agar is a type of dietary fibre, it is not a component of traditional dietary fibre found in plant foods like fruits, vegetables, and grains.
  • Therefore, it does not fit within the typical categories of dietary fibre components like cellulose, pectin, and lignin.

Cellulose (Option A) is a complex carbohydrate and a major component of plant cell walls. It is insoluble in water and forms the structural framework of plant cells. Cellulose is considered a type of dietary fibre and provides bulk to the diet, promoting regular bowel movements and aiding in digestive health.

Pectin (Option B) is a soluble fibre found in fruits, particularly in the peels and pulp. It acts as a thickening agent and is commonly used in food processing and cooking. Pectin has been shown to have various health benefits, including lowering cholesterol levels and improving gastrointestinal health.

Lignin (Option C) is a complex, non-carbohydrate polymer found in plant cell walls. It is insoluble in water and provides structural support to plant tissues. Lignin is considered a type of dietary fiber and contributes to the overall fiber content of plant-based foods. While it is not digestible by humans, lignin plays a role in promoting bowel regularity and maintaining gut health.

choices.text: Human milk < Buffalo milk < Curd < Cheese
Human milk < Curd < Buffalo milk < Cheese
Curd < Human milk < Buffalo milk < Cheese
Curd < Human milk < Cheese < Buffalo milk

questions.text: Arrange the following milk/products in terms of increasing content of fat
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Human milk generally has the lowest fat content among the options listed.
  • Curd, which is made from milk, retains much of the fat content of the original milk.
  • Buffalo milk typically contains more fat than cow's milk, so it is placed before cheese.
  • Cheese, being a concentrated dairy product, often has the highest fat content among the options listed.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest glycaemic index?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dextrose has a high glycaemic index because it is readily available for absorption and utilization by the body, causing a rapid spike in blood glucose levels.

  • Dextrose, also known as glucose, is a simple sugar that is rapidly absorbed into the bloodstream, leading to a quick increase in blood sugar levels.
  • Glycaemic index (GI) is a measure of how quickly a carbohydrate-containing food raises blood glucose levels after consumption compared to a reference food, typically glucose or white bread.
  • Foods with a high GI are rapidly digested and absorbed, leading to a quick spike in blood sugar levels.

choices.text: Binds the cholesterol-containing bile in the gut, thus helping in lowering total serum cholesterol
Helps in the control of blood glucose

questions.text: The beneficial health effects of dietary fibre include
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Advantages of Dietary Fibre:

  • Improves bowel function by: (Option A)
    • Increasing faecal bulk
    • Softening stools
    • Enhancing the frequency and regularity of bowel movements (Laxation effect)
  • Helps lower blood cholesterol levels (Cholesterol attenuation) (Option B)
  • Assists in blood glucose control (Blood glucose attenuation) (Option C)
